awd_abstract_narration:
The assignment of students to various schools in their district can have important implications for student achievement and student welfare. A large body of theoretical work in Economics studies the design of matching markets. Several school districts including New York, Chicago, Boston, Cambridge, Denver and New Orleans employ mechanisms in which students rank schooling options and a computerized algorithm matches students to schools. A similar mechanism is used to assign medical residents to residency training positions. The design and their implementation is based on theoretical insights for which Alvin E. Roth and Loyd Shapley were awarded the Nobel Prize in 2012. However, the empirical study of these markets is lagging. An important barrier to progress is methodological since most mechanisms still in use today do not make it safe for agents to report their true preferences. This fact may have important implications on student welfare, and fairness. The primary goal of the proposed research is to develop new methods for estimating preference models using data from matching markets, and apply them to analyze policy relevant questions that have been thus far theoretically and empirically intractable.

The proposed research will develop a new method for estimating a discrete choice model using reported preferences from an assignment mechanism where participants do not have the incentive to report their preferences truthfully. Previous research estimating preferences has largely been limited to settings where particular institutional/theoretical features support treating reported preferences as truthful or specific details of the mechanism provide partial information on preferences. Our baseline approach analyzes information that is revealed by assuming that the observed reports are optimal. We then analyze relaxations of this strong form of rationality to study what can be learned under weaker assumptions on agents' sophistication. The methodological analysis involves studying large sample properties of a two-step estimator, extending techniques from the literature on demand models to study non-parametric identification of the model, and comparing computational methods for implementing the estimator. As an application, the proposed research will study the elementary school admissions system in Cambridge, MA that uses a variant of the (old) Boston mechanism, which is susceptible to manipulation. Subsequently, we plan to compare preference estimates under varying assumptions on the sophistication to assess their sensitivity to economic assumptions.

por.por_cntn:
The award supported the study of how various school choice systems affect student well-being. The work informs the market design literature on how best to organize the assignment of students to public schools and provides methods for quantitatively analyzing design issues.

The two main projects that resulted from the award are studies of the school choice reforms in New York City, and the school assignment system in Cambridge, MA. The first project analyzed the allocative effects of the redesign of NYC's High School Match in 2003. Prior to 2003, admission decisions were processed in three rounds and were uncoordinated across schools. We found that admission offers were concentrated amongst students and rejected offers were not passed on to others that were unassigned. The end of a primary and a supplementary assignment process still left a third of students unassigned. These students were placed administratively to a neighborhood school, typically a large zoned school with lower performance metrics than the schools these students voluntarily applied to. Students expressed their dissatisfaction by exiting the NYC Public School system and seeking enrollment elsewhere.

Following the reforms, only about one-tenth of students were left unassigned after the primary and supplementary rounds. Exits from the public school system fell from 8.5% to 6.4%, and students not enrolling in their assigned schools went down from 19% to 11%. These statistics suggest that coordinated systems result in greater satisfaction overall, but there may still have been redistribution with certain groups benefiting at the cost of others. We estimated a model that quantified student preferences for various schools in terms of willingness to travel to see whether the benefits of the new system were widespread. Our estimates suggest that while some groups benefit more than others, heterogeneity in preferences resulted in all groups (based on demographics, achievement categories or residence location) benefited from the change.

Indeed, the new system did an excellent job of matching students. We found that the student welfare gains from coordination dominate the effects further relaxation of constraints on student assignments via priorities or requiring stability. The assignment mechanism in NYC realized 80% of the potential gains from choice as measured by the difference between a neighborhood assignment system and the student-optimal assignment. This compares with less than a third for the uncoordinated system.

The exercise in New York City was conceptually simple because truthful reports are optimal in the system. Assignment systems with straightforward incentives are rare relative to manipulable systems. This can complicate advising a school district on the allocative effects of various policies that affect assignments, or inferring which schools are popular. Additionally, one may question why such mechanisms survive despite the widely understood incentive problems.

The second project supported by the award tackles these issues. It studies the Cambridge Controlled Choice Plan for elementary school assignments. Similar systems are commonly used in the rest of the world, and they prioritize students at their higher ranked choices. Specifically, students ranking a school first gain higher priority at that school that all other students, including those with siblings currently attending the school. The risk of “losing your priority” creates incentives to strategize.

The incentives to manipulate in this mechanism poses several important questions. First, how does analyze student preferences if the stated rank-order lists cannot be taken on face-value? This exercise itself is important in determining the true desirability of schools since some districts invest in schools based on ranking data or measure the performance of the system based on the number of students that get into their top choice. Second, why do these systems persist despite their incentive and fairness problems?

To answer the first question, we develop a new empirical methodology in which we reinterpret the choice of a rank-order list as a choice of the probability of assignment into various schooling options. This reinterpretation allows a revealed preference method over uncertain prospects to be used as an empirical strategy. The results from the grant enable statistical analyze student preferences for most school choice mechanisms used today.

Our results indicate significant bias in the estimated preferences for schools if the strategic issues are not incorporated into the analysis. Naive estimates would suggest that only 16% of students are not assigned to their most preferred choice, but accounting for gaming the estimates suggest that 25% of students are not placed at their top choice despite the favorable treatment at the stated top choice.

The method also influences our evaluation of various school assignment systems. We find that the screening benefits of a manipulable mechanism are indeed positive if agents are fully sophisticated. However, this conclusion relies heavily on optimal behavior. Models with biases in student beliefs would favor systems like the ones used in New York instead of in Cambridge.
